title: Thomas Shannon saves mother from crash wreckage moments after breaking his own back
text:
A 21-year-old man heroically saved his mother from a wreckage despite suffering from a broken back moments earlier in the crash.

Thomas Shannon and his mother Linda were driving home from the cinema in Windellama in the Southern Tablelands of NSW, when they were suddenly confronted by flood water on January 27 last year.

Thomas, who was a learner driver at the time, didn't see the oncoming danger and the car was sent smashing into a fence post and rolling on the ground.

Thomas Shannon (left) heroically saved his mother (right) from a car crash wreckage despite having had his own back broken moments before

'I remember seeing the ground outside the driver's side window. When I came to [consciousness] in the car, I noticed the windscreen was gone. I'd lost my glasses in the crash so everything was pretty blurry,' Mr Shannon told the Daily Telegraph.

The adrenaline kicked in immediately and Thomas quickly went into first-responder mode which he had learned through his volunteering in the Windellama Rural Fire Service.

He called out to his mother who didn't respond straight away but was heard murmuring moments later.

'My neck was pinned between the roof of the car and the seat. I came to because Thomas was calling me,' Mrs Shannon recalled.

Thomas worked quickly to remove himself and his mother from the car after he smelled what he believed was petrol and burnt plastic.

'He got out of the car, came to my side and managed to get the door open. He had to push on the seat hard to break it back so he could get me out,' Mrs Shannon said.

Thomas, who was a learner driver at the time, didn't see the oncoming danger and the car was sent smashing into a fence post and rolling on the ground

There was no phone reception in the remote location so Thomas requested a passing driver to stay with his mother while he went and got his father for help.

Mrs Shannon suffered knee, foot and facial injuries including the loss of 10 teeth and a huge gash on the top of her head.

Thomas suffered a fractured T11 vertebrae, something he only realised hours later when paramedics were assisting his mother.

His grandmother, Margaret Shannon, nominated Thomas for a Pride of Australia Award for his heroic act.

'Thomas... is a very quite achiever showing care for everyone he helps and carries out his RFS duties with great thought well beyond his years. All the while doing his TAFE Course. He goes beyond the call of duty to protect the community he lives in,' she said.

authors: Mahnaz Angury For Daily Mail Australia
